user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_ConsoleOutput_Impl:
```c
void OS_ConsoleOutput_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    size_t                        StartPos;
    size_t                        EndPos;
    size_t                        WriteSize;
    OS_console_internal_record_t *console;

    console  = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_console_table, *token);
    StartPos = console->ReadPos;
    EndPos   = console->WritePos;

    OS_BSP_Lock_Impl();

    while (StartPos != EndPos)
    {
        if (StartPos > EndPos)
        {
            /* handle wrap */
            WriteSize = console->BufSize - StartPos;
        }
        else
        {
            WriteSize = EndPos - StartPos;
        }

        OS_BSP_ConsoleOutput_Impl(&console->BufBase[StartPos], WriteSize);

        StartPos += WriteSize;
        if (StartPos >= console->BufSize)
        {
            /* handle wrap */
            StartPos = 0;
        }
    }

    OS_BSP_Unlock_Impl();

    /* Update the global with the new read location */
    console->ReadPos = StartPos;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_ConsoleOutput_Impl:
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
extern OS_console_internal_record_t OS_console_table[OS_MAX_CONSOLES]
...
typedef struct
{
    char device_name[OS_MAX_API_NAME];

    char *          BufBase;        /**< Start of the buffer memory */
    size_t          BufSize;        /**< Total size of the buffer */
    volatile size_t ReadPos;        /**< Offset of next byte to read */
    volatile size_t WritePos;       /**< Offset of next byte to write */
    uint32          OverflowEvents; /**< Number of lines dropped due to overflow */
    bool            IsAsync;        /**< Whether to write data via deferred utility task */
} OS_console_internal_record_t
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
static inline osal_index_t OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    return token->obj_idx;
}
...
int32 OS_ConsoleCreate_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    OS_impl_console_internal_record_t *local;
    OS_console_internal_record_t *     console;
    pthread_t                          consoletask;
    int32                              return_code;
    OS_VoidPtrValueWrapper_t           local_arg = {0};

    console = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_console_table, *token);
    local   = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_console_table, *token);

    if (token->obj_idx == 0)
    {
        return_code = OS_SUCCESS;

        if (console->IsAsync)
        {
            if (sem_init(&local->data_sem, 0, 0) < 0)
            {
                return_code = OS_SEM_FAILURE;
            }
            else
            {
                /* cppcheck-suppress unreadVariable // intentional use of other union member */
                local_arg.id = OS_ObjectIdFromToken(token);
                return_code  = OS_Posix_InternalTaskCreate_Impl(&consoletask, OS_CONSOLE_TASK_PRIORITY, 0,
                                                               OS_ConsoleTask_Entry, local_arg.opaque_arg);

                if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
                {
                    sem_destroy(&local->data_sem);
                }
            }
        }
    }
    else
    {
        /* only one physical console device is implemented */
        return_code = OS_ERR_NOT_IMPLEMENTED;
    }

    return return_code;
}
...
void OS_BSP_ConsoleOutput_Impl(const char *Str, size_t DataLen)
{
    ssize_t WriteLen;

    while (DataLen > 0)
    {
        /* writes the raw data directly to STDOUT_FILENO (unbuffered) */
        WriteLen = write(STDOUT_FILENO, Str, DataLen);
        if (WriteLen <= 0)
        {
            /* no recourse if this fails, just stop. */
            break;
        }
        Str += WriteLen;
        DataLen -= WriteLen;
    }
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I did not find any code fragments that are clearly unreachable. Reasoning by function:

- OS_ConsoleOutput_Impl: The while loop condition (StartPos != EndPos) governs entry; none of the statements inside are after an unconditional return/continue/goto that would make subsequent code unreachable. The two branches (StartPos > EndPos and else) both compute a positive WriteSize for legitimate buffer scenarios; the subsequent StartPos update and wrap handling (StartPos >= console->BufSize -> StartPos = 0) are reachable when wrap occurs (StartPos becomes equal to BufSize). When StartPos <= EndPos the else branch produces WriteSize = EndPos - StartPos and makes StartPos == EndPos, which exits the loop normally. There is no code that cannot be reached because of constant-true/false conditions or unconditional jumps.

- OS_BSP_ConsoleOutput_Impl: The inner while (DataLen > 0) may break when write() returns <= 0; that break simply exits the local loop to stop further writes — it does not make any subsequent code unreachable. There are no unconditional returns or unreachable branches in this helper.

- OS_ConsoleCreate_Impl and related macros: The control flow (if token->obj_idx == 0 ... else ...) provides mutually exclusive reachable branches depending on token->obj_idx. The nested checks (console->IsAsync, sem_init success/failure, return_code checks) are all conditional and reachable depending on runtime state; there are no unreachable labels or code after unconditional returns.

- Macros and inline functions (OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET, OS_ObjectIndexFromToken): their expansions do not introduce unreachable code; they are simple index/lookup operations.

Given the provided code and related definitions, there are no obvious always-unreachable statements or blocks to flag for MISRA Rule 2.1. If there are additional translation-unit- or build-time invariants (e.g., BufSize == 0, invalid ReadPos/WritePos values, or guarantees making a branch always false) not shown here, those would need examination, but with the supplied code none of the fragments are provably unreachable.
